Jeffrey Epstein Update
A fellow inmate assure us it was suicide in a post on Medium
(By Ann Coulter - May 30, 2025)
Excerpts:
[F]or almost the entirety of 2019, I was incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York City for the the crime of underreporting my income.
During that time, I was employed by the psych department as the chief suicide watcher (inmate companion coordinator), a title that had me scheduling my fellow inmates for their four-hour shifts watching other detainees whoâ€™d decided they wanted to kill themselves.
â€¦
[I] didnâ€™t really see Jeffrey as suicidal until the judge denied his bail. Faced with the possibility heâ€™d never leave prison, it was then that Epstein ratcheted down emotionally.
Epstein had convinced the psychs that he was no longer suicidal â€¦ I saw it differently. Iâ€™d never seen him look more depressed.
After that night, Jeffrey was moved back to protective custody [and] seized the moment.
â€¦
MCC was an extremely secure facility (El Chapo couldnâ€™t even escape). To sneak a murderer in and out would have taken an extensive conspiracy involving many officers to get the job done.
If that conspiracy had actually existed, it would have unraveled quickly. â€¦[The officers] simply werenâ€™t that slick.
The idea that the unitâ€™s cameras had been shut off so nobody would see the murder (one forwarded conspiracy) is a thought I found laughable. Most of the prisonâ€™s cameras werenâ€™t operational. We knew that.
..
[Inmate Brown] occupied the cell next to Jeffrey Epsteinâ€¦. Brown returned to report that the night Epstein died, nobody entered the unit - and he heard Epstein tearing up sheets in the wee hours.
Brown had absolutely no agenda in telling me this save exposing the truth as he saw (and knew) it. Jeffrey Epstein killed himself, there is no doubt.

5/30/25PETER NAVARRO Bá»Š Há»I GIáº¤Y VÃŒ BAO TRá» NGáº I Vá»€ THÆ¯Æ NG CHIáº¾N
Sau quÃ¡ nhiá»u trá»¥c tráº·c vá» thÆ°Æ¡ng chiáº¿n, â€˜cÃ´ng trÃ¬nh sÆ°â€™ (chá»¯ ráº¥tâ€¦ Trung Cá»™ng) cá»§a trÃ² ngu lÃ  Peter Navarro Ä‘ang bá»‹ Ná»™i cÃ¡c cá»§a Donald Trump chiáº¿u cá»‘. NgÆ°á»i ta cÃ³ nhiá»u áº©n dá»¥ diá»…n táº£ tÃ¬nh tráº¡ng báº¥t thÆ°á»ng mÃ  táº¥t yáº¿u Ä‘Ã³: Navarro Ä‘Æ°á»£c dáº«n ra phÃ¡p trÆ°á»ng; dÃ¢y xÃ­ch dáº«n con chÃ³ giÃ  bá»‹ thu ngáº¯n, Ä‘á»ƒ bá»›t cháº¡y long nhong; nháº¹ nháº¥t lÃ  cho Ä‘i chÆ¡i chá»— khÃ¡câ€¦.
Tá» Telegraph cá»§a Anh thÆ°á»ng sá»›m cÃ³ tin vá» ná»™i tÃ¬nh cá»§a Trump. ÄÃ¢y lÃ  thÃ­ dá»¥:
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/.../peter-navarro-donald.../...
Trumpâ€™s cabinet turns on tariff architect
Members scrutinising Peter Navarro after â€˜smack in faceâ€™ court ruling halting levies
Peter Navarro speaks to the media outside the White House in Washington after a court ruling blocking Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs
Peter Navarro speaks to the media outside the White House in Washington after a court ruling blocking Donald Trumpâ€™s sweeping tariffs Credit: Nathan Howard
(By Cameron Henderson - The Telegraph - 30 May 2025 3:30pm BST)
The architect of Donald Trumpâ€™s sweeping tariffs is facing scrutiny from cabinet members after the levies were halted by judges.
A New York court ruled on Wednesday that Mr Trumpâ€™s â€œliberation dayâ€ tariffs were illegal and overstepped the authority of the Oval Office.
The ruling is a â€œhuge smack in the faceâ€ for Peter Navarro, one of the presidentâ€™s closest advisers, a source close to the White House told The Telegraph.
Members of Mr Trumpâ€™s cabinet are now closely scrutinising Mr Navarro, who is widely viewed as the architect of the presidentâ€™s tariff scheme.
â€œNavarro has been given enough rope to hang himself,â€ the source said.
Mr Navarro, left, is widely believed to have been the architect of the president's scheme
Mr Navarro, left, is widely believed to have been the architect of the presidentâ€™s scheme Credit: Andrew Harnik
The Manhattan-based Court of International Trade on Wednesday ruled that the US president overstepped his authority by imposing across-the-board duties on imports from nations that sell more to the United States than they buy.
The court said the US Constitution gives Congress exclusive authority to regulate trade with other countries and cannot be overridden by the presidentâ€™s emergency powers to safeguard the US economy.
The administration won a temporary reprieve on Thursday with an appeals court temporarily blocking the previous ruling halting tariffs.
Mr Trump has claimed broad authority to issue tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), which is meant to address â€œunusual and extraordinaryâ€ threats during a national emergency.
Mr Navarro is understood to have counselled the president to use the IEEPA to implement the measures.
The law, which Mr Trump is the first president to use to implement tariffs, has historically been used to impose sanctions on enemies of the US or freeze their assets.
A source close to the White House said Mr Navarro will face backlash over the decision from within Mr Trumpâ€™s cabinet, potentially paving the way for him to be replaced by Robert Lighthizer, the presidentâ€™s former trade secretary.
Mr Lighthizer sparked a trade war with Beijing during Mr Trumpâ€™s first term by imposing tariffs on hundreds of billions of dollars of Chinese goods.
The international trade lawyer was a key adviser to the presidentâ€™s 2024 campaign but was passed over for a cabinet position in the administration.
Shortly after the court ruling, which quashes the tariffs Mr Trump imposed on Canada, Mexico and China, the White House filed a notice of appeal.
â€œWe think we have a strong case. Yes, we will immediately appeal and try to stay the ruling,â€ Mr Navarro confirmed to Bloomberg.
He added that the court ruling showed the White House could also use alternative legal methods to impose a baseline 10 per cent tariff and higher reciprocal duties on other countries.
â€œSo nothing has really changed here in that sense... We are still, as we speak, having countries call us and tell us they want a deal,â€ Mr Navarro said. â€œThese deals are going to happen.â€
Mr Navarro served as a trade adviser during Mr Trumpâ€™s 2016 election campaign and has long advocated for a radically protectionist trade policy.
He spent four months in jail last year for contempt of Congress after he refused to cooperate with an investigation into the Jan 6 riots.
Addressing the trade courtâ€™s slap down, Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, blamed the decision on â€œactivist judgesâ€ and called for the Supreme Court to intervene.
The ruling was handed down by a three-judge panel, who were nominated to the court under the presidencies of Ronald Reagan, Barack Obama and Mr Trump.
â€œThere is a troubling and dangerous trend of unelected judges inserting themselves into the presidential decision making process,â€ Ms Leavitt said.
â€œAmerica cannot function if president Trump, or any other president for that matter, has their sensitive diplomatic or trade negotiations railroaded by activist judges.â€
She added: â€œBut ultimately, the Supreme Court must put an end to this for the sake of our Constitution.â€

HÃ´m nay, Thá»© SÃ¡u, thá»‹ trÆ°á»ng sá»¥t giÃ¡ khi tháº¥y Trump Ä‘áº£ kÃ­ch Báº¯c Kinh vá» trÃ² tariff. NhÆ°ng sau cÃ¹ng sáº½ láº¡i nhÆ°á»£ng bá»™, nhÆ° máº¥y láº§n trÆ°á»›c thÃ´i!
https://www.wsj.com/.../stock-market-today-tariffs-trade...
Stock Market Today: S&P 500 Falls After Trump Hits Out at China
Court stays ruling voiding Trumpâ€™s levies; Bessent earlier said China trade talks are 'a bit stalled'
Last Updated:
30 May 2025 at 10:50 am New York Time
Stock indexes slipped Friday, after President Trump accused China of violating its deal with the U.S., injecting fresh volatility into what has been a whirlwind month for investors.
Chinaâ€™s reluctance to approve exports of rare-earth materials is one reason Trump said Beijing is violating the agreement, U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said. China is â€œslow-rollingâ€ its compliance, particularly on the export licenses, according to Greer.
The new tension casts a shadow on what has been a largely positive, if turbulent, period for U.S. stocks. As of early Friday, both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite were on track for the biggest monthly gains of the year.
Yesterday, a court stayed a ruling voiding Trumpâ€™s sweeping levies. The administration could yet win its appeal, but could also deploy alternative measures to institute or maintain tariffs. Specifically, the White House is considering a trade-act provision that allows for levies of up to 15% for 150 days.
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said late Thursday the legal turmoil around tariffs hasn't had any impact on trade negotiations. He said a couple of "very large deals" were close but that talks with China were "a bit stalled."
Despite May's uptick in markets, American consumers remained gloomy about the economy. The final reading for a closely watched sentiment index came in unchanged from April, although up from an historically low preliminary reading.
Separate data indicated the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation gauge slowed more than expected, to a 2.1% annual rate as of April. On a core basis, inflation also slightly undershot expectations.
Meantime, the U.S.'s trade deficit for goods shrank substantially last month, as new tariffs weighed on imports.
In recent trading:
The S&P 500 and Nasdaq fell modestly, while the Dow industrials wavered.
Bond yields edged lower. Benchmark Treasury yields settled Thursday at 4.423%.
Chinese tech stocks fell before Trump's latest statement. Bessent's earlier remarks weighed on hopes for a U.S.-China trade deal.
Bitcoin prices dropped below $106,000.
Oil futures declined. OPEC+ is expected to announce crude output hikes for July after a meeting this weekend.

TGIF: Scammander in Chief
President Donald Trump speaks in the Oval Office. (Andrew Harnik via Getty Images)
Trump plays a game of chicken. The White House doles out fishy pardons. Democrats get all masculine. Elon departs D.C. The Macron slap. And much more.
(By Nellie Bowles - The Free Press - 05.30.25 - TGIF)
Welcome back to your week in review. My only housekeeping announcement is that new merch has hit the store just in time for those who use â€œsummerâ€ as a verb or live in the White House: Free Press golf balls. Please add your best tagline for them in the comments.
â†’ I canâ€™t afford a pardon: The White House vending machine is giving out pardons this week! Scott Jenkins, a Virginia sheriff convicted of conspiracy, fraud, and bribery for accepting piles of cash in exchange for letting rich folks have fake sheriffâ€™s badges, got a Trump pardon. So did reality show stars and fraudsters Todd and Julie Chrisley, whoâ€™d initially been sentenced to 12 and 7 years, respectively, for conspiring to commit bank fraud and (obviously) conspiracy to commit tax evasion. And a random tax criminal has also been pardoned - right after his mother gave Trumpo $1 million at a fundraising dinner. That gentleman had been ordered to pay the state $4 million restitution alongside his prison sentence, so the $1 million payment to the president is a better deal in many ways.
At this point, paying your taxes directly to the Trump family is a better deal and probably safer than using the IRS. Trump wanted to slash red tape, and slash red tape he has. Now he just puts a briefcase on the table and nods. I pay my cleaning lady in cash, and thatâ€™s how I will probably pay my taxes now too. Every April, I will throw wads of dirty bills in a brown paper bag, scrawl my Social Security number (666-66-6666) on it, and leave it at Tiffany Trumpâ€™s door. How do I calculate whatâ€™s owed? Well, itâ€™s based on my income, of course, plus extra in my case for being a blue state libtard and for not losing the baby weight. Deductions offered for pictures of a local ballot showing Trump written in for every option, especially library board; being a guy with beer cozies and acceptably strong biceps because we need more of you fellows; and being a woman with anything above a B-cup. I get two of three deductions this year!
After Trump held a crypto dinner last Thursday night, crypto moguls who paid to be there felt scammed that the president didnâ€™t even stick around at the event theyâ€™d hoped to do their own scams at. I saw someone describe him as the apex scammer. Our Scammander in Chief. Give me a pen and a ballot for the Upper West Side library committee because I need to add one more name.
â†’ Vlad, why would you be so nuts? The president is baffled by Vladimir Putinâ€™s recent behavior, writing on Truth Social: â€œIâ€™ve always had a very good relationship with Vladimir Putin of Russia, but something has happened to him. He has gone absolutely CRAZY! He is needlessly killing a lot of people, and Iâ€™m not just talking about soldiers.â€ Our Vladster, killing civilians? Acting kooky? Thatâ€™s not the dictator I know and love. Trump added: â€œLikewise, President Zelensky is doing his Country no favors by talking the way he does. Everything out of his mouth causes problems, I donâ€™t like it, and it better stop.â€ That part I understand. Heâ€™s a jealous man, and when someone steals his shtick, you best watch out.
Trump seems to really hate war, so he probably genuinely believes he can post his way out of it. And letâ€™s see. Itâ€™s not like Bidenâ€™s way of standard American forever-war methodology was working in Ukraine, which was a shock to me because that way worked so well elsewhere in the past. Like, I canâ€™t imagine missing a ski season on Afghanistanâ€™s Koh-i-Baba slopes and ending the day with a glass of Iraqi Freedom wine at my favorite bar off the Dick Cheney Expressway. Anyway, keep posting at him, Trumpo. If that doesnâ€™t do it, then weâ€™ll tag in the nuclear weapon team (Hillary Clinton on her second Scotch) to put an end to this and all of Eastern Europe. Itâ€™s getting to be enough already.
In other Russia news, a new statue of Joseph Stalin in a Moscow metro station was unveiled this month. President Putin has called Stalin an â€œeffective manager,â€ and has said that enemies of Russia use the â€œexcessive demonizationâ€ of Stalin to attack â€œthe Soviet Union and Russia.â€ Stalin is back, big time. Interesting that â€œeffective managerâ€ is being used here to describe a man who facilitated the death of millions - and not efficiently. But Iâ€™m not a businessman.
And in final presidential news, a Financial Times-coined acronym for Trump has been taken up on Wall Street and it is: TACO. As in: Trump Always Chickens Out. Like, donâ€™t worry, heâ€™ll drop the tariffs. TACO! When asked about this new phrase in a press conference, the president was furious: â€œDonâ€™t ever say what you said, thatâ€™s a nasty question. To me thatâ€™s the nastiest question.â€ Later he added: â€œThey will say, oh, he was chicken, he was chicken, thatâ€™s so unbelievable.â€ Being asked about the phrase TACO is the nastiest question? Well, there goes my sit-down with the president.
â†’ Have you met Pete? The new macho, bearded, chill, and cool Pete Buttigieg is here. Gone is the paternity leaveâ€“taking, gay prideâ€“touting trans-portation secretary. And, like every good presidential candidate, heâ€™s signaling that itâ€™s okay to throw the old Dems under the bus. Asked what he would have done differently in 2020 he said, right off the bat: â€œOne, for the love of God, figure out a way to get the schools open sooner. We got very knee-jerk about this, and. . . the costs were profound.â€
I hate to say it, but it was a great answer and Iâ€™m starting to like my all-American Mayor Pete again. Beep beep, a little pinch to my neck, a new SIM card just installed, and itâ€™s Pete! Except this time heâ€™s wearing his military fatigues. Iâ€™m all in. Hands up if you canâ€™t wait to see how Chasten decorates for Christmas!
On cue, Taylor Lorenz, voice of the American progressive, one-time star of The New York Times before The Washington Post poached her to be their star before getting so big she started her own site, had this to say: â€œPete saying he would have â€˜opened the schools soonerâ€™ in 2020 aka killing MORE vulnerable people faster, sacrificing teachers and educators (and kids!) lives to force them back into unventilated buildings w[ith] no protections. Disgusting how Dems have fully embraced far right eugenics.â€ This is my bat signal. Moderates, get on your tandem bikes. Itâ€™s Pete oâ€™clock. The vibe is: Weâ€™re gay, but not too gay. Open the schools.
â†’ The State Department has a. . . Substack: The State Department is blogging on Substack. As if our competition wasnâ€™t hot enough, now we have to deal with the literal State Department. If you donâ€™t restack their posts theyâ€™ll designate you as a foreign terrorist; if you comment with anything negative, theyâ€™ll send you to El Salvador. Very similar to the TGIF comment moderation policies. Theyâ€™re now writing about how World War II created a new world order based on â€œglobal liberalismâ€ that is destroying Western civilization, which is exactly what I was going to write this week. The State Department continues: â€œOur hope is that both Europe and the United States can recommit to our Western heritage, and that European nations will end the weaponization of government against those seeking to defend it,â€ which was pulled directly from our Mission page. They even write about how thousands of Britons have been arrested for online posts. Itâ€™s edgy analysis that tiptoes right up to the line (like, innovative use of describing America and Europeâ€™s shared â€œfamilial tiesâ€ instead of race). Anyway, keep an eye out for these up-and-coming center-right Substackers. I wonâ€™t know how I feel if the State Department makes us one of their recommended publications until it happens, so letâ€™s check in next week.
â†’ The continued reckoning: A postmortem on Kamala Harrisâ€™s campaign cited a â€œperception gapâ€ as one of the reasons she lost, saying voters believed she held positions that she didnâ€™t. â€œOver 80% of swing voters who chose Trump believed Harris held positions she didnâ€™t campaign on in 2024, including supporting taxpayer funding for transgender surgeries for undocumented immigrants (83%), mandatory electric vehicles by 2035 (82%), decriminalizing border crossings (77%), and defunding the police (72%).â€ But Harris had, in fact, supported all of these positions. Like, she is on record supporting each of those positions (here, here, here, and here). So itâ€™s not really a perception problem so much as a reception problem, like these ideas are not popular even though I support them. Thereâ€™s a sense among Dems that people should simply ignore the things that are unpopular and that referencing them is fake news. Like, how dare you talk about the surge of migrants coming through our new open borders thanks to swift changes from the Biden admin. Yes, itâ€™s technically true, but itâ€™s disinformation-coded.
And finalized polling data from Trumpâ€™s victory was posted this week, so now we have the exact numbers on everything. Between 2020 and 2024, Trump gained 6 percent of black voters, 11 percent of Asian voters, and 21 percent of Hispanic voters, while gaining only 2 percent of white voters. Hispanics and Asians. Mainstream media spent years blaming white guys sitting at random Midwestern diners only for the big reveal to be Hispanics and Asians. That noise you hear is a stampede of 23-year-old New York Times reporters heading to Chinatown and Spanish Harlem to ask about how exactly they internalized that much white supremacy, how they assimilated so strongly in the wrong direction. Iâ€™ll write your lede, guys: â€œWhile standing at the taco truck, one could hear the calls of mi hombre and mi hermano. Unspoken that day: mi hermana.â€
â†’ Musk lashes out at the â€œbig, beautiful billâ€: During an interview with CBS News Sunday Morning, Elon Musk commented on the huge new Republican spending bill. He said he feels â€œdisappointed to see the massive spending bill, frankly, which increases the budget deficit, not just decrease[s] it, and undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing.â€ He said that â€œI think a bill can be big, or it could be beautiful. But I donâ€™t know if it could be both.â€ It cannot be both. A bill is like a woman, and cannot be both smart and pretty (Iâ€™m kidding, donâ€™t yell at me). I will say that I had high hopes for DOGE, despite the fact that this meant pinning hopes to someone named Big Balls. But to those balls my dreams were pinned, genuinely. So this is all pretty sad. Speaking of balls, just a reminder to buy ours, in case you forgot already. See ya on the green!
More on the CIAâ€™s Star Wars fan website, a professor of honesty fired for fraud, a slap to the face of Franceâ€™s president, and much, much more. But first: a cartoon from Mr. David Mamet.
â†’ Leave Bruce alone: A bar in New Jersey canceled a performance by a Bruce Springsteen tribute band after the real Springsteen called Trump â€œcorrupt, incompetent, and treasonousâ€ while on tour in England. Citing the barâ€™s MAGA clientele, the bar owner said that a Springsteen cover band would be â€œtoo risky at the moment.â€ And: â€œWhenever the national anthem plays, my bar stands and is in total silence, thatâ€™s our clientele. Toms River is red and wonâ€™t stand for his bullâ€”.â€
My conclusion: All political groups can be snowflake babies. All men yearn to see blood in the streets. See, I absolutely love Bruce Springsteen, and sure, I find his photo shoots and podcasts with Obama to be a little cringe, as the kids say, but I also donâ€™t care. Politics shouldnâ€™t get in the way of enjoying â€œTunnel of Love,â€ a goddamn masterpiece. I take my neutrality seriously. Weâ€™re blasting the new Ye banger in our house right now. Art knows no borders! (Weird, I have no idea why the preschool teachers just requested an urgent meeting.)
â†’ CIA ran a Star Wars fan site: The CIA secretly ran a Star Wars fan site to covertly communicate with overseas informants, according to an amateur security researcher. 404 Media (a fabulous tech news site) discusses the research and how â€œtyping a password into the ordinary looking websitesâ€™ search bar actually triggered a login process for sources to then communicate with the CIA.â€ The site is apparently one of many the CIA operated, and frankly, Iâ€™m impressed at the skill level and whimsy of our federal government here. My question is what other niche nerd communities are run by the spooks. Obviously, all Magic: The Gathering groups. But I have a friend whoâ€™s really into the knitting community, and she goes to yarn shops wherever she travels. Do I need to ask her for more specifics? Is The Free Press a black ops site? Help!
â†’ Honesty professor fired for fraud: Harvard officially fired Francesca Gino, who studied honesty and ethical behavior, after the university accused her of data fraud. Gino, who was one of Harvardâ€™s highest-paid employees, making over $1 million a year, manipulated data to better support her research. And who first discovered this fraud? The boys at a little behavioral science blog called Data Colada, run by Uri Simonsohn, Leif Nelson, and Joseph Simmons. The key takeaway here is not that a star has fallen but that so much behavioral â€œscienceâ€ is fake. If you want to know about human nature, you donâ€™t need a study. Weâ€™re not that unique or complex. Just sit quietly and imagine the worst version of yourself (Lustful? Envious? Proud?). Would you steal the cookie and lie about stealing it? You would. Thereâ€™s your Harvard PhD in behavioral psychology.
â†’ China testing the vibes of colonialism: China unilaterally declared that certain disputed zones in the waters between China and South Korea were â€œno-sail zones.â€ The zones, at least partially designated for military exercises, went into effect last Thursday and were scheduled to end this past Tuesday. As the Trump administration flirts with the â€œmultipolar worldâ€ vision that the Kochs and the Soroses have been pushing for years, weâ€™ll start to see some of the new poles in action. That action looks like China taking Taiwan, for sure, but maybe also South Korea, just a little bit. For a sense of the intellectual underpinning of this movement, check out the Quincy Institute, launched with funding from (yes) Charles Koch and George Soros. TGIF obviously wants a unipolar world that bends around America, and ideally around me. My children already know where the no-sail zones are in our house (the entire house, minus their playpen).
â†’ Emmanuel Macron gets slapped: Emmanuel Macron, the president of France, got shoved in the face by his wife Brigitte Macron. Footage taken of the couple standing by an open plane door showed Brigitte manhandling her husband. Macronâ€™s aides first said that the video was AI-generated and disseminated by Russian accounts, my go-to excuse when caught shoplifting on CCTV. Once the video was authenticated, the Ã‰lysÃ©e Palace said the video portrayed a â€œmoment of togetherness.â€ Itâ€™s how I display tenderness, too. With both hands, I grab my subject by the jowls and shove them. They did meet when he was 15 and she was 39. So thereâ€™s a lot going on there already, and I really donâ€™t want to know that much more about their sexual dynamic.
â†’ Economics R so hard: New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani is proposing a sweeping new policy: rent freezes! So everyoneâ€™s rent freezes right where it is, or it will be tased. I donâ€™t have the energy to explain all the reasons this ends up making housing more expensive, but I shouldnâ€™t have to. I was told that the dawn of AI would make us more intelligent, and yet here I am, presented with this charismatic and nonsensical mayoral candidate who has made every effort he can not to understand basic economics. Meanwhile, the group Youth Against Displacement has put out a perfect video explaining that: â€œSupply and demand is NOT how housing works.â€ Pray tell, why? Okay, the video answers that, but itâ€™s a bad answer. Bad socialists! Bad! Stop doing this. Male Oprah: Go back to Albany.
â†’ No more grades: The San Francisco Superintendent of Schools was hoping to see what might happen if we just said YOLO and gave everyone Aâ€™s. A new â€œGrading for Equityâ€ plan for the cityâ€™s students led to a wave of criticism this week. The plan included things like eliminating homework and weekly tests from counting toward final grades (which would be determined by one final exam that students can take multiple times). Students could submit assignments late or not show up to class at all, and it wouldnâ€™t affect their grades. They could score as low as 80 and receive an A. Why not!
There is a dark notion on the left that some children just canâ€™t be taught skills like fluent reading. That itâ€™s unfair and mean and racist to force all kids to take the same math test if outcomes on exams fall along demographic lines. The writer Wesley Yang reminded me of the best illustration of this. A few years ago, progressive superstar Jamaal Bowman, then a congressman, posted a cartoon of different animals (including a fish, a monkey, a penguin, a dog, and an elephant) facing a teacher who says: â€œFor a fair selection everyone has to take the same exam: Please climb that tree.â€ On the political right, this movement is known as â€œHuman Biodiversity.â€ Itâ€™s all a bit fatalistic for me. Amid the backlash, San Francisco is now pausing the â€œeverybody gets an Aâ€ program. . . at least until people stop paying attention.
â†’ Univeral Basic Income fails again: Now itâ€™s just getting sad. The National Bureau of Economic Research found that income had no impact on any measure of childhood wellness and development, per a big new study. Researchers gave $333 a month to one set of impoverished families and $20 a month to a control group, then tracked whether the cash reduced the developmental gap between poor children and better-off children. No impact. At all. On anything. Itâ€™s honestly really strange. But itâ€™s the perfect justification I need to spend more and spend now rather than save for the kids to have an inheritance. Anyway, it just leads back to fatalism: Maybe the behavior patterns of the middle class are the key, not the money itself. But then, how do you explain a wealthy yet dysfunctional family? Much to mull here. Need to call my dad about this one.
â†’ Things that are not antisemitism: The Democratic Socialists of America â€œLiberation Caucusâ€ has announced its support for Elias Rodriguez, the suspect arrested for slaughtering two Israeli Embassy staffers outside D.C.â€™s Capital Jewish Museum last week. Hereâ€™s the statement signed by the DSA Liberation folks and a bunch of others: â€œAs imperialism has made the entire world its battlefield, it is justified to fight it, by any means necessary, without regard for geography.â€ And: â€œ[T]here must be consequences for genocidal [Z]ionist imperialism, and those consequences are righteous.â€ Chants of resistance is justified are the new cool thing in Chicago. And the major anti-Zionist protest group Unity of Fields is officially transitioning into â€œA MILITANT FRONT AGAINST THE US-NATO-ZIONIST AXIS OF IMPERIALISM.â€ Militant means their plan is to kill more. So, anyone who has ever said the Passover prayer that ends with Next year in Jerusalem, well, weâ€™re all fair game. The killings are anti-Zionism, though, not antisemitism, write mainstream lefty thinkers. It just happens to be that Judaism keeps bringing up Israel. Have you considered not saying prayers? And a leader of the Palestine Writes festival is posting about how there is no such thing as the Jewish people. You learn new things every day.
Meanwhile, Wired, whose reporters always refer to The Free Press as dangerous, published this how-to on building your own gun in honor of an accused vigilante killer:
â†’ Tate Brothers face criminal charges in the UK: Andrew and Tristan Tate are facing a total of 21 charges in the UK, including rape, actual bodily harm, and human trafficking. The pair first faced charges in Romania, where they were placed under house arrest for several months. The more recent charges date from incidents between 2012 and 2015, before their move to Romania. Andrew and Tristan said they â€œcategorically reject all chargesâ€ and are â€œvery innocent men.â€ The men who travel the world talking about beating women seem to treat women pretty badly, all around the world. Nothing funny here, just a nod of approval to the UK authorities for finally trying to arrest someone worthwhile.
â†’ Always remember to remember remembering: Manchester United recently posted this: â€œOn 22 May 2017, something tragic happened in our city. We will always remember those who were lost on that day.â€ And they included a black square that reads: â€œAlways remembered. We will never forget.â€ Thatâ€™s it. No details. Well, honestly Iâ€™d already forgotten and needed to Google it. Oh, riiight. A British-born Islamist set off a bomb at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester Arena, killing 22 people. Or, just a random day to randomly remember. We will never forget. Hold space in your mind to grasp the tragedy. Donâ€™t think too hard, though, about what it was.
â†’ King Charles doing a land acknowledgment for land he could give up: From his throne in Canada (so based), King Charles began his speech with a land acknowledgment. Yes, by the Grace of God, King of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and of His other Realms and Territories said the following: â€œI would like to acknowledge that we are gathered on the unceded territory of the Algonquin Anishinaabeg people. This land acknowledgment is a recognition of shared history as a nation. While continuing to deepen my own understanding, it is my great hope that in each of your communities and collectively as a country, a path is found toward truth and reconciliation in both word and deed.â€ The man who is literally the King of Canada. Whose empire rests on his people having been the OG greatest colonialists to march this earth. Sir, you live in Buckingham Palace. I promise you, you do not want truth and reconciliation in both word and deed.
And if youâ€™re stressed about anything between now and next week, remember: TACO.

5/30/25GIá» THÃ“I KIÃŠU BINH LÃ€ GÃ‚Y KHÃ“ CHO GIÃO CHá»¦!
Kimberley Strassel rá»i Ä‘Ã¨n vÃ o thÃ³i kiÃªu binh cá»§a J.D. Vance khi Ä‘áº£ kÃ­ch Chá»§ tá»‹ch Tá»‘i Cao PhÃ¡p Viá»‡n John Roberts: Ä‘Ã³ lÃ  gÃ¢y khÃ³ cho Trump. CÃ³ khi vÃ¬ váº­y mÃ  háº¿t hy vá»ng vÃ o cuá»™c báº§u cá»­ 2028!
https://www.wsj.com/.../vance-courts-trouble-for-trump...
Opinion - Potomac Watch
Vance Courts Trouble for Trump
He takes on Chief Justice John Roberts. Thatâ€™s unhelpful to the administration.
Kimberley A. Strassel
(By Kimberley A. Strassel - WSJ - May 29, 2025 - Appeared in the May 30, 2025, print edition as 'Vance Courts Trouble for Trump'.)
image
U.S. Vice President JD Vance in Las Vegas, May 28. Photo: Ethan Miller/Getty Images
If the British coined the term â€œtoo clever by half,â€ Vice President JD Vance might own the political update of â€œtoo smart by 99%.â€ And Donald Trump might wonder at what point he asks his veep: Please stop helping - at least when it comes to Mr. Trumpâ€™s greatest legacy and biggest asset, the U.S. Supreme Court.
Mr. Vance recently offered his own take on the â€œroleâ€ of that body, in particular Chief Justice John Robertsâ€™s â€œprofoundly wrong sentimentâ€ that the judiciary exists to â€œcheck the excesses of the executive.â€ The vice president finger-wagged that this was â€œone-halfâ€ of the job; the â€œother halfâ€ was to stop a â€œsmall but substantial numberâ€ of courts from telling â€œthe American people theyâ€™re not allowed to have what they voted for,â€ namely â€œimmigration enforcement.â€ Also, to be â€œextremely deferentialâ€ to the â€œpolitical judgmentâ€ made by â€œthe peopleâ€™s elected president of the United States.â€
Mr. Vance did at least preface his comments with a warning that they may prove â€œinflammatoryâ€ - before inflaming away.
Students of law - or of, well, grade school - no doubt quickly picked up on the first problem. The foundation of the U.S. system is the constitutional separation of powers, checks and balances. Congress has the purse. The executive has the sword. The judiciaryâ€™s power is to settle â€œall Casesâ€ and â€œControversiesâ€ â€œarisingâ€ under the Constitution and other laws. Far from being â€œprofoundly wrong,â€ Chief Justice Robertsâ€™s sentiment was profoundly basic. To have a court that jumps to the will of a president or a changeable voting majority is to have... Venezuela. Mr. Vance, a Yale Law School graduate, surely would have disapproved of the courtâ€™s rubber-stamping Joe Bidenâ€™s student-loan forgiveness or vaccine mandates - even though Mr. Biden won an election.
Students of logic will find in the veepâ€™s comments an impressive array of logical fallacies, from the straw man to the false dilemma. Chief Justice Roberts didnâ€™t, as Mr. Vance suggests, claim â€œcheckingâ€ was its main role, or single out the president. The chief uncontroversially noted that the role of the court was to â€œobviously decide cases, but in the course of that, check the excesses of Congress or the executive.â€
Nor did he suggest lower courts were immune from checks. He probably didnâ€™t feel it necessary, given that every opinion the high court issues is a review of something a lower court did. A significant number of its recent decisions have brushed back activist judges -allowing the administration to proceed, among other things, in removing independent agency heads, freezing grant money, and ending the temporary protected status program for Venezuelans. As for immigration, the court has continued to give the president the usual wide latitude - with the basic requirement of due process.
Which brings us to students of politics, who will recognize these comments as political malpractice. The most enduring legacy of the first Trump term was the cementing of a conservative Supreme Court majority that continues to thoughtfully transform the legal landscape. Religious freedom. The end of Roe v. Wade. The major-questions doctrine. The end of Chevron deference. Reining in the bureaucracy. Second Amendment rights. Presidential immunity.
And the question of what legacy emerges from Mr. Trumpâ€™s second term rests squarely in the hands of that same court. Mr. Trump is proving to be the most energetic executive in decades, challenging the establishment to rethink the status quo on everything from the federal workforce and government grant making to the power of independent agencies. Most of these questions are destined for the justices - the same people Mr. Vance and others in Mr. Trumpâ€™s orbit have taken to badgering.
Mr. Vance fashions himself shrewd and likely thinks his comments serve the multiple purposes of proving loyalty to his boss, whipping up the base, and (not-so) subtly warning the court of backlash if it fails to rule as heâ€™d prefer. The vice president might consider that jurists are well-versed in the art of clever arguments; they know what heâ€™s doing. Or that they arenâ€™t easily intimidated - see the Brett Kavanaugh hearings. But they can get irritated and annoyed, and less motivated to do much beyond basic requirements. How helpful is that? And Mr. Vance might consider that his criticism is essentially a slap at the presidentâ€™s judgment in appointing these justices and other lower-court judges (who occasionally rule against him) in the first place.
The temptation by Mr. Vance and other officials to let loose on the courts will grow as more issues ripen and the administration wins some and loses some (like this weekâ€™s tariff case). Mr. Trump has so far refrained from going full-frontal on the judiciary, a political instinct that has served him well, given the stakes. At some point, he might suggest that the vice president leave the politics to the guy actually in charge of the executive branch.
7
5/30/25Sá»° THáº¬T ÃŠ CHá»€ Vá»€ JOE BIDEN, Äáº¢NG DÃ‚N CHá»¦ VÃ€ BÃO CHÃ Má»¸
Hoa Ká»³ Ä‘ang bá»‹ cháº¥n Ä‘á»™ng vÃ¬ cuá»‘n â€œOriginal Sinâ€ do Jake Tapper vÃ  Alex Thompson trÃ¬nh bÃ y sá»± toa táº­p cá»§a cháº¿ Ä‘á»™ Joe Biden nháº±m che giáº¥u sá»± tháº­t vá» Biden. Cuá»‘i tuáº§n, ta nÃªn cháº­m rÃ£i Ä‘á»c ká»¹ bÃ i Bari Weiss phá»ng váº¥n hai tÃ¡c giáº£ cá»§a cuá»‘n sÃ¡ch:
(Bari Weiss Ä‘Ã£ sÃ¡ng láº­p vÃ  lÃ  chá»§ biÃªn cá»§a The Free Press, vá»›i má»™t tiáº¿t má»¥c tháº­t sá»± mang tÃ­nh cháº¥t lá»‹ch sá»­ cÃ³ tá»±a Ä‘á» lÃ  Honestly...]
https://www.thefp.com/p/jake-tapper-and-alex-thompson-on
Jake Tapper and Alex Thompson on the Great Biden Cover-Up
Former president Joe Biden during a farewell event with staff at Joint Base Andrews in Suitland, Maryland on Friday, January 20, 2025. (Demetrius Freeman/The Washington Post via Getty Images)
The authors of the new book â€˜Original Sinâ€™ share all the details of how President Biden and his closest aides misled the American people.
(By Bari Weiss - The Free Press - 05.29.25 - Honestly with Bari Weiss)
In 2023 and 2024, there were many things that were unsayable. Perhaps the most unsayable - at least in legacy media circles - was this: The President of the United States was not capable of being president because he was no longer mentally fit.
Those people who did break the taboo - who dared to notice Bidenâ€™s countless gaffes and stiff gait, those who recognized the reality of old age - including special counsel Robert Hur - were written off or smeared. Videos of the president - clips of Biden tripping and misspeaking - were rebranded by The New York Times as â€œcheap fakes.â€ People were told to disbelieve their eyes and ears.
Itâ€™s now the spring of 2025. Donald Trump is the president. And now the unsayable things are being said - most dramatically in Jake Tapper and Alex Thompsonâ€™s new book, Original Sin: President Bidenâ€™s Decline, Its Cover-Up, and His Disastrous Choice to Run Again.
Tapper, a CNN anchor, and Thompson, an Axios reporter, interviewed more than 200 people for this book, which illuminates Bidenâ€™s mental decline, his enablers, and how the country was effectively run by committee in the midst of his clear cognitive impairment.
For those of us who thought it was bad - it was actually so much worse than anyone could have imagined.
Alex and Jake have chosen to call the effort to hide Bidenâ€™s decline a â€œcover-up.â€ Those are choice words from two mainstream media insiders, invoking memories of Watergate and Iran-Contra. And the cover-up they are referring to, of course, is that of the Biden family and the close circle of advisers around them, many of whom are still delusional about Bidenâ€™s state.
But cover-up might be the term that many Americans would use to describe the pressâ€™s coverage of Biden. How did ordinary people see more than people with White House press passes? And what does this all say about human nature, transparency, and groupthink?
This is a really illuminating conversation about presidential power, the lengths some will go to keep it, and how the media failed to report the story of a lifetime.
You can listen to the full conversation below, watch the video recording, or scroll down to read an edited transcript.
On how Biden hid the truth about his deterioration:
Bari Weiss: For people that havenâ€™t read Original Sin, tell us a little more about the crutches that allowed a nonfunctioning Biden to work.
Alex Thompson: All politicians prefer certain reporters at press conferences, and are usually directed to call on them. What started as an effort to make Biden look good grew more pronounced as he struggled. Every time Biden had a press conference, the White House press team handpicked the reporters. It became a crutch - they chose reporters whoâ€™d ask about topics he was comfortable with.
I covered the Biden White House for four years and never got a question. Once they picked you, the press team would cozy up and ask, â€œWhat are you interested in?â€ And sometimes reporters were just a bit too honest.
They filtered what the public saw by handpicking reporters. On the note cards - members of the cabinet told us there were scripts for cabinet meetings, not just when cameras were on, but even off-camera, before the meetings. This goes back to 2021. Aides, worried about him going off script, would go to cabinet secretaries and ask, â€œWhat do you want to ask?â€ or â€œIf he asks this, whatâ€™s your answer?â€ One cabinet secretary literally described them as scripts. And sometimes the off-camera meetings were even weirder and more stilted.
BW: How so?
AT: Without cameras, they stuck to preselected answers. The White House would say cabinet meetings are always stilted, but even by that bar, they were odd, at times discursive, and troubling.
Jake Tapper: Just to pick up on that - these things evolve or devolve. In October 2023, they had their last cabinet meeting for almost a year. Thatâ€™s shocking.
BW: How often are cabinet meetings typically held?
JT: Maybe four or five times a year. Depends on the president.
BW: And theyâ€™re usually sites of debate or passionate conversation about major issues?
JT: They should be. Not every presidency is like that, but if youâ€™re the leader of the free world, itâ€™s a key way to learn whatâ€™s going on in your administration. One-on-ones may be more productive, sure, but not having any meetings for a year is stunning.
AT: They were also shielding cabinet members from smaller meetings too. Several told us that.
JT: It started with teleprompters in the basement during the 2020 campaign. In 2021, it continued - understandable, we were still in Covid. But by 2023, he had teleprompters set up in the homes of donors for fundraisers. For meetings with 40 or 50 people.
Bari, if you were speaking to that size crowd - for The Free Press or a bar mitzvah - youâ€™d speak for ten minutes. Anyone could. But the president couldnâ€™t. And by 2023, this wasnâ€™t the exception. It was the rule. People started getting alarmed - but privately.
On how Biden and his aides squashed internal dissent:
BW: Where were the voices around Biden - people like Jake Sullivan or Antony Blinken? People with integrity who understand the stakes of having a commander in chief who canâ€™t function past 4 or 5 p.m.? What were they saying in 2022 and 2023?
AT: Two things. Even though the foreign policy team saw it, their view was distorted. If Biden got the right topic, he could clock back in. He was more engaged on foreign policy than other areas.
JT: Sometimes a lot more. Toward the end, when unrest in Syria and Assadâ€™s fall happened, Biden was engaged. Weâ€™re not saying he was a vegetable. But he had really bad moments.
AT: Still, we talked to cabinet secretaries who didnâ€™t believe he could handle a crisis that might unfold at 2 a.m.
BW: You quote a secretary saying, â€œIf you expect the president to be woken up at 2 a.m., Biden was not capable of that in 2024.â€ Your reporting suggests he wasnâ€™t capable of it in 2022 either.
AT: Definitely not in 2023. The secretary said 2024, but the signs were earlier.
BW: So how is no one internally saying, â€œThis is not normalâ€? Where are those people?
AT: In Biden World, the defining virtue is loyalty. Dissent isnâ€™t a conversation - itâ€™s seen as disloyalty. Two things happened: People like pollster John Anzalone, who raised concerns, were sidelined. He raised questions about a real reelection process, and was told, â€œNo, thanks.â€ Heâ€™s not part of the reelection.
That happened to many. Loyalty is enforced by Biden and Anthony Bernal, who was Jill Bidenâ€™s chief of staff. People got the memo: Donâ€™t speak up or youâ€™ll be pushed out.
Some things were done quietly - Bob Bauer, Bidenâ€™s longtime lawyer, had the Democratic National Committee get Hunterâ€™s laptop, create a dossier of the worst details, and present it privately to Joe and Jill Biden. The message: This time, itâ€™s all coming out. It will be painful.
JT: And that evidence would be introduced at trial.
AT: Exactly. But those were subtle gestures. No one, despite concerns about Bidenâ€™s ability to beat Trump or serve until 2029, got in his face.
On how Bidenâ€™s condition affected his decision-making:
BW: There were failures in Bidenâ€™s presidency - Afghanistan, the border, inflation. To what extent were those failures tied to his acuity?
JT: In June 2024, Senator Michael Bennet, a Colorado Democrat, goes to the White House for an immigration event. Biden glitches - not just forgetting Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkasâ€™s name, but something deeper.
Bennet leaves thinking, â€œThis is why our immigration policy is such a mess - he canâ€™t manage the competing interests.â€ Mayorkas expected a 2021 order to secure the border. Obama deported many - he was called â€œdeporter-in-chief.â€ But that crackdown never came. Bennet thought Biden simply couldnâ€™t handle it.
When it comes to the American Rescue Plan, Bidenâ€™s big 2021 spending bill, former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers warned it would be inflationary. We donâ€™t know how much of that Biden was briefed on. His team wasnâ€™t just hiding him from the world - they were hiding the world from him. Poll numbers, information - it was unhealthy. So yes, quite a bit was tied to his acuity. And weâ€™re still reporting for the paperback.
On the role of Hunter Biden:
JT: I donâ€™t have high regard for Hunter based on his role here. Itâ€™s tragic. His addiction and chaos caused a lot of his fatherâ€™s decline. The plea deal falling apart in summer 2023, then the trial and conviction in 2024 - those were moments of real deterioration for Biden.
Itâ€™s not just fear of Hunter going to jail - itâ€™s fear of relapse or suicide. Biden already lost his wife and daughter in 1972, his son Beau in 2015. Losing his last child? He couldnâ€™t recover from that.
Hunter, meanwhile, saw this as a chance for redemption - standing up for his dad, pushing him to run again, fighting back against Special Counsel Robert Hur and anyone trying to push him out.
At one point, Hunter talked about running for mayor of Wilmington. He wanted to show he had what Beau and his dad had. But in pushing Biden to run again, he couldnâ€™t see what was happening.
The best advice - obvious in hindsight - was to take the legacy of one term and let a new generation of Democrats step forward. But he pushed his dad to stay. In 2023 and 2024, he wanted the White House to be the Hunter Biden defense organization. They said no. He and his allies were sidelined.
After the poor debate performance, the family blamed senior communications adviser Anita Dunn. She left the White House and joined the super PAC. Thereâ€™s a price for crossing the Bidens - excommunication. Even loyal aides like Dunn and Bauer lost that battle with Hunter.
On what made Biden drop out:
BW: Given the drama, the three weeks after the debate feel anticlimactic. In the book, Schumer paints himself as the hero who finally speaks truth to power. But where was he before?
JT: Heâ€™s the only one we found who told the president not to run. Not Obama, Pelosi, Jeffries, Katzenberg - only Schumer.
BW: And thatâ€™s what made Biden finally decide?
AT: It was a combination. He didnâ€™t want to divide the party. Maybe he could win the nomination, but it would be ugly. Then he caught Covid, was isolated in Rehoboth.
JT: And it really sucked. If youâ€™re 81 and have Covid, itâ€™s serious.
AT: Schumer being blunt - saying the majority of senators didnâ€™t think he should run - meant something to Biden. He spent 36 years in the Senate. Other operatives made the case there was another path, that he couldnâ€™t win anymore. I also think there may be more we donâ€™t know yet. This is the first draft, not the last.
JT: Weâ€™ll add more in the paperback. He was so â€”
AT: So defunct. He still thinks he couldâ€™ve won. He believed it was winnable. And if you think Trump is a threat, why drop out? Was it just Covid?
BW: Or was it that he has metastatic prostate cancer?
AT: I wasnâ€™t speculating that, butâ€”
BW: Because thatâ€™s the perfect transition. Right before your book drops, they announce he has stage four prostate cancer. And people like Dr. Zeke Emanuel - hardly Biden critics - say thereâ€™s no way it was a recent diagnosis. Heâ€™s probably had it for 5â€“10 years. Did they lie?
JT: We donâ€™t have reporting that contradicts their version: diagnosed Friday, announced Sunday.
BW: Right before the book drops.
JT: People are skeptical - we get that. Even people in the Biden White House are skeptical. But we donâ€™t have the reporting.
What it underscores is how opaque this all is. These are the most sensitive, personal subjects. We believe presidents should disclose everything - every medication, every test result. But thatâ€™s not how it works. Thereâ€™s sympathy for leaders on health. Weâ€™re on the honor system. Is it possible he hasnâ€™t had a PSA test since 2014? Maybe. But thatâ€™s the blood test relevant to the prostate, and for someone running the country - not the average 70-year-old - youâ€™d think theyâ€™d want to know.
Jake Tapperâ€™s response to online criticism:
BW: The backlash that Iâ€™m seeing is largely coming from X. I donâ€™t go on Bluesky. Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s happening there too.
JT: I had to get off on October 8, 2023, for obvious reasons.
BW: Right, so a lot of what Iâ€™m seeing, Jake, is not directed at Alex, who has been reporting on this.
JT: Iâ€™m seeing some nasty stuff about Alex. Iâ€™ll share it with you later.
BW: I would say itâ€™s largely focused on you, perhaps because you have a huge show on CNN every night, perhaps because theyâ€™ve read Alexâ€™s wonderful reporting in Axios - who knows. But itâ€™s more focused on you and there are some specific clips that are getting circulated a lot, specifically one where Lara Trump is on your show.
JT: It was October 2020, it was four and a half years ago.
BW: She basically suggests what the reporting in this book suggests - that sheâ€™s looking at an enfeebled president whoâ€™s not fully compos mentis. And you sort of glibly dismiss her. And I wondered if you could reflect on that a little bit. I know you called her, but when youâ€™re watching that clip, what version of yourself do you see?
JT: I donâ€™t want to make excuses for it. We live on TV and so we die on TV. Things that we say age well or age poorly - and that one aged poorly.
I see somebody who is interviewing a member of the Trump family right before an election, and I think that Joe Biden is old, but I do not have any reports suggesting that he is in cognitive decline. I know that I have been shocked by the things that members of the Trump family are saying about President Biden - then Vice President Biden. Don Jr. is out there literally suggesting heâ€™s a pedophile on Instagram and such. I didnâ€™t think much of what she was saying, but she was right and I was wrong.
I think that there is a big, big difference between the Joe Biden of 2020 and the Joe Biden of 2024, as our reporting bears out. And thereâ€™s also a big, big difference between what I am saying now - having reported this book - and the information she had. Although again, our reporting suggests that there were moments of cognitive impairment that he was having as far back as 2015.
I would also say, in terms of my reflection on this, just in the last couple weeks, some of those clips that you mentioned - the Lara Trump one is totally fair. Thatâ€™s fine. Itâ€™s accurate. I said it. I did it. I own it.
But some of the clips are deceptively edited. Iâ€™m not going to call them â€œcheap fakes,â€ but they are me saying what The Washington Post is accusing somebody of doing, and they edit out me citing The Washington Post. Or itâ€™s me interviewing Franklin Foer about his book on Biden and making it sound as though I am saying what I am paraphrasing Franklin Foer saying. And on and on. Whatever - this is the world that weâ€™re in.
But when the publicists for the book went to The Wall Street Journal editorial page or Fox News - when I reached out to a Republican senator - who all used these clips without even researching them or anything like that and said â€œThese are out of context,â€ they were not greeted with the response of, â€œOh, Iâ€™m so sorry, Iâ€™ll correct the record,â€ or â€œThatâ€™s not true,â€ or â€œLet me see what the reality is.â€ What was the response? They donâ€™t care. They ignore it. It doesnâ€™t matter. Moving on.
Iâ€™m okay reflecting and looking back and saying, â€œI wish Iâ€™d done this better.â€ I wish I had been more aggressive. What Lara Trump said turned out to be accurate based on my reporting. And here is our book showing this reporting. And I think this book is important. The reason why this book is getting attention is because airing those clips and making fun of President Biden is not actually reporting. Itâ€™s commentary - and itâ€™s fine, and Iâ€™m not criticizing it - but what we do in this book is actually show what was going on behind the scenes.
But Iâ€™m fine being the person that reflects and says, â€œYou know, I got that wrong,â€ or â€œI could have done that better,â€ in contrast to these critics who, in the name of media criticism, are being untruthful and donâ€™t care.
BW: But would you say that, looking back at the body of your work during the Biden White House, you could have brought a level of skepticism, scrutiny, and curiosity to this story?
JT: Of course. There are very few members of the legacy media that I donâ€™t think could say that. But I will say that in October 2020, I interviewed Joe Biden, and I asked if he would take a pledge to be transparent about his health. And in October 2022, the only time I had an interview with him during his presidency, I pointed out that the American people think heâ€™s too old. Whenever heâ€™s asked about that, he says, â€œWatch me.â€ Theyâ€™re watching him. They still think that.
I had skeptical interviews with Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre in 2023. And I was not a Robert Hur basher. I completely thought that he was accurate. And I didnâ€™t understand what I was seeing from the White House or from other journalists that didnâ€™t see what we were all seeing.
So I think that there is reporting that Iâ€™m proud of that is also part of the record. But on the whole, I wish these 200 sources had talked to us two years ago. And I wish Iâ€™d known what I know now. I would not say I was incurious. I would say that I was one of the many people who was asking about this and was lied to - over and over.
You have to remember, the Biden people were not only lying to the press and to the public - they were lying to donors, cabinet secretaries, Democratic members of Congress. A cover-up, and almost a successful one. Even though we all saw him aging, we didnâ€™t know he had these moments of nonfunctioning. It suggests that thereâ€™s a lot of people in on something. And whether they were doing it because they believed it or they had been told it, at the end of the day, the Democrats did this. At the end of the day, the Biden family and the politburo - his senior aides - did this.
And yes, there were those of us who should have pushed back more. But if you canâ€™t get officials to tell you itâ€™s really bad behind the scenes - let me tell you how bad it is - I donâ€™t know what more we could have done. And I wish that those people had been more willing to talk to the press.
On continued Democratic reluctance to blame Biden:
JT: I think that one of the things thatâ€™s been surprising is that I would think that there would be a Democratic presidential candidate in 2029 or whatever who would come out and say something along the lines of: â€œWe have to be honest with the American people. We canâ€™t let that happen again.â€
And you have seen glimmers of it from Rep. Ro Khanna, Senator Chris Murphy. Pete Buttigieg said something about how it was obvious that Biden shouldnâ€™t have run again. People just dipping their toe in it.
I think that there are a lot of Democrats who still donâ€™t want to talk about this and still donâ€™t want to confront the fact that Joe Biden and his team were part of a cover-up and a deception campaign that ended up delivering Donald Trump back to the White House.
They just donâ€™t want to accept it. They want to blame me, or New York Times reporter Maggie Haberman, or Trump, or Fox, or whatever. But thereâ€™s no degree among the Democratic base to reckon with what they are part of.
Editorâ€™s note: This interview has been edited for clarity. The views and opinions expressed by guests of Honestly are solely those of the guests and do not necessarily reflect the views, opinions, policies, or positions of Honestly or The Free Press.

5/30/25THÆ¯Æ NG CHIáº¾N Cá»¦A TRUMP: Gáº¶P THá»œI BI Sáº®C CHO NÃŠN CÃ‚U GIá»œ...
Bi Sáº¯c lÃ  BÃ­, nÃªn láº¡i Ä‘Æ°a káº» báº¥t tÃ i vÃ´ tÆ°á»›ng cháº¡y Ä‘i cháº¡y láº¡i tá»« DÃ¢n Chá»§ sang Cá»™ng HÃ²a - vÃ  láº§n nÃ o cÅ©ng tháº¥t cá»­ - lÃ  Peter Navarro váº½ ra lá»‘i thoÃ¡t: háº¯n chÆ°a há» pháº£i kiáº¿m Äƒn trong Ä‘á»i sá»‘ng... nÃªn sáº½ tÃ¬m ra!
TÆ°á»ng thuáº­t bi tháº£m cá»§a WSJ:
Economy - Trade
Trumpâ€™s Team Plots Plan B for Imposing Tariffs
If a court appeal fails, presidentâ€™s advisers are considering a stopgap tariff regime
(By Gavin Bade and Kim Mackrael - WSJ - May 29, 2025)
President Trump holding a signed executive order.
President Trump in April with a signed executive order on tariffs. Photo: Leah Millis/Reuters
Key Points - What's This?
* The administrationâ€™s tariff strategy was undermined when a trade court found that it was illegal for President Trump to impose sweeping duties by using emergency economic powers.
* A federal appeals court allowed duties to stay in effect while the administrationâ€™s appeal moves forward.
* An alternative plan aims to buy time for devising individualized tariffs to counter unfair practices.
WASHINGTON - President Trumpâ€™s trade team is readying its Plan B.
The administrationâ€™s tariff strategy was undermined when a court this week found it was illegal for Trump to impose sweeping duties by using emergency economic powers. A federal appeals court on Thursday allowed his duties to stay in effect while the administrationâ€™s appeal moves forward, but U.S. officials are weighing their options should they need to find a new legal authority to impose the presidentâ€™s steep tariffs, which he argues will help rebalance trade in Americaâ€™s favor.
The potential pivot reflects the challenges to Trumpâ€™s aggressive trade policy, which relied on a novel interpretation of trade law. Typically, tariffs are imposed using targeted authority delegated to the president by Congress, but Trumpâ€™s team relied on little-used emergency powers to impose the bulk of his wide-ranging second-term tariffs quickly.
With that strategy under threat, the presidentâ€™s team is weighing a twofold response, according to people familiar with the matter.
First, the administration is considering a stopgap effort to impose tariffs on swaths of the global economy under a never-before-used provision of the Trade Act of 1974, which includes language allowing for tariffs of up to 15% for 150 days to address trade imbalances with other countries, the people said. That would then buy time for Trump to devise individualized tariffs for each major trading partner under a different provision of the same law, used to counter unfair foreign trade practices.
That second step requires a lengthy notification and comment process, but is seen by administration officials as more legally defensible than the tariff policy that was found to be illegal this week. The alternative provision has been used many times in the past, including for Trumpâ€™s first-term tariffs on China.
Peter Navarro speaking outside the White House.
Peter Navarro, senior counselor for trade and manufacturing, is floating alternative strategies. Photo: Nathan Howard/Reuters
The conversations remained fluid, and the administration hadnâ€™t made a final decision, the people added. The administration could wait to implement any alternative plans after the federal appeals court allowed Trumpâ€™s emergency tariffs to stay in place during the appeals process.
The White House and the Office of the U.S. Trade Representative didnâ€™t respond to requests for comment. Karoline Leavitt, the White House press secretary, said Thursday that the administration is weighing other options to impose tariffs as it appeals the court rulings, but she didnâ€™t give specifics.
Peter Navarro, senior counselor for trade and manufacturing, appeared to confirm that the administration is considering a twofold alternative tariff plan, which would first use Section 122 of the 1974 trade law, and then Section 301.
â€œThose are the kinds of thoughtsâ€ the economic team is considering, he said when asked about those provisions on Bloomberg TV. Navarro also suggested that the administration could use the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act of 1930, which has a provision that allows for tariffs on nations that discriminate against America. The U.S. could also expand the use of tariffs imposed citing national-security concerns.
All of the options under consideration now were discussed in the early weeks of the administration, but officials opted to instead impose tariffs under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, also known as IEEPA. The law had never been used before to impose tariffs but allowed the administration to move quickly to impose levies on virtually every global trading partner.
In its decision Wednesday, the U.S. Court of International Trade struck down Trumpâ€™s use of IEEPA to address trade deficits. In doing so, the court pointed to Section 122, the measure Trumpâ€™s team is now weighing as a stopgap policy, saying part of federal law already grants explicit authority to address â€œlarge and serious balance-of-payments deficits.â€
WSJ explains how markets reacted after a federal trade court struck down President Trumpâ€™s tariffs and the implications for international trade. Photo: Brendan Smialowski/AFP/Getty Images
Pivoting to a different tariff authority could pose risks. If the administration moves to use a different law, that could be seen by courts as admitting defeat in ongoing appeals in the IEEPA case.
â€œThe administration could quickly turn to other tariff authorities, but doing so while the ruling is under judicial review could be seen as a lack of confidence in the final decision,â€ said Everett Eissenstat, who served as deputy director of the National Economic Council in Trumpâ€™s first term.
Trumpâ€™s alternative plan would likely still face legal challenges, said Peter Harrell, who served as senior director for international economics on the Biden administrationâ€™s National Security Council. But both elements are on firmer legal ground than the IEEPA tariffs, he said.
The Court of International Trade â€œseemed to indicate that Section 122 is how youâ€™d address a trade deficit,â€ Harrell said. Section 301, he added, has a long case law history, and action under that provision would likely be upheld as long as the Trump administration can point to unfair trade practices from each targeted nation. In all, the plan is â€œcertainly more defensible than the IEEPA tariffs,â€ he said.
Trumpâ€™s potential alternative tariff plan has an advantage: Using another law to reimpose the tariffs could smooth over any interruptions in tariffs because of the courtâ€™s ruling, preserving Trumpâ€™s leverage in ongoing trade talks. In a filing asking for an emergency stay on the Court of International Tradeâ€™s decision, the administration said the ruling â€œjeopardizes ongoing negotiations with dozens of countries by severely constraining the Presidentâ€™s leverage and undermining the premise of ongoing negotiations.â€
That appeared to contradict National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett, who insisted Thursday that trade negotiations will continue unabated and that three deals are close to being completed. Navarro similarly said that â€œnothing has really changed.â€
The ruling on Wednesday came days after the president threatened to impose 50% tariffs on the European Union and then quickly pulled back to allow for negotiations until July 9 - a deadline now thrown into question.
A rise in global stocks supports the EUâ€™s argument that tariffs arenâ€™t good for anyone, Spanish Minister of Economy Carlos Cuerpo said Thursday. He said the bloc is taking â€œa constructive approach to reaching an agreement and, if possible, even reducing barriersâ€ below pretariff dispute levels.
Some analysts said the ruling could ease the path for a trade deal between the U.S. and EU by removing, if the decision survives Trumpâ€™s appeal, a key sticking point from the negotiations.
Ignacio GarcÃ­a Bercero, a former EU trade official, said that removing the U.S.â€™s 10% tariff on European imports and the threat of further across-the-board tariffs would allow trade negotiators to focus instead on the U.S.â€™s sectoral tariffs on such industries as steel and automobiles. Those were implemented on national-security grounds, not using the economic-powers law, and will be unaffected by the continuing court battle.
â€œIf thereâ€™s a more pragmatic attitude from the United States and also, of course, from the European Union, one would have the opportunity to try to use this to find a more balanced type of agreement that is in the interest of both sides,â€ he said.
Write to Gavin Bade at gavin.bade@wsj.com and Kim Mackrael at kim.mackrael@wsj.com

5/30/25NGA PHáº M Tá»˜I ÃC TRONG CHIáº¾N TRANH
Báº£n tin cá»§a RFE/RL cho biáº¿t cÆ¡ quan LiÃªn Hiá»‡p Quá»‘c Ä‘Ã£ Ä‘iá»u tra vÃ  lÃªn Ã¡n quÃ¢n Nga lÃ  cá»‘ tÃ¬nh báº¯n háº¡ xe cá»©u thÆ°Æ¡ng táº¡i Ukraineâ€¦
https://www.rferl.org/.../ukraine-russia.../33428429.html
Russian Drone Attacks In Ukraine's Kherson Amount To War Crimes, Says UN
(By RFE/RL - May 29, 2025 09:55 CET)
The UN report alleges that Russian soldiers deliberately targeted ambulances with drones.
Russia's military has committed war crimes and crimes against humanity in its drone attacks on civilian targets in the southern Ukrainian region of Kherson, a new United Nations report has found.
The report by Independent International Commission of Inquiry on Ukraine, issued on May 28, was the latest evidence pointing to possible crimes allegedly committed by Russian civilian or military authorities in Ukraine.
"Russian armed forces have committed the crimes against humanity of murder and the war crimes of attacking civilians, through a months-long pattern of drone attacks targeting civilians on the right bank of the Dnieper River in Kherson Province," the commission report said.
Ukrainian investigators have compiled evidence on what they say are tens of thousands of potential war crimes, allegedly committed by Russian troops. That includes the alleged execution of civilians in the town of Bucha in March 2022.
In late 2022, several months after the start of the all-out invasion, Ukrainian forces succeeded in partially pushing Russian troops out of the Kherson region. Russian forces withdrew from the western banks of the Dnieper River, across the river to the east, which is also part of the Kherson region.
Since then, Russian troops have continued to bombard towns and cities on the opposite bank, including the city of Kherson. Ukrainian forces tried in 2023 to establish a bridgehead on the Dnieperâ€™s eastern banks, to push Russian troops further away, but that effort failed.
A group of Ukrainian marines sail from the riverbank of the Dnieper at the front line near Kherson on October 14.
Nearly 150 civilians have been killed in the drone campaign that the commission said started in the summer of 2024; and hundreds more wounded; many as they were doing their daily routines in and out of their homes. Drone operators used real-time video feeds to track and strike civilians, the report said.
Ambulances, which are protected under international law, have also been targeted.
Russian Attack Drones Hunt Down Individual Civilians In Ukraine
The Russian attacks "were committed with the primary purpose to spread terror among the civilian population, in violation of international humanitarian law," said the expert panel, which operates under the United Nations Human Rights Council.
The International Criminal Court, which operates independently of the United Nations, has brought war crimes and crimes against humanity charges against President Vladimir Putin and a top Kremlin adviser for overseeing the forcible transfer of tens of thousands of children out of Russian-occupied Ukrainian territories.
The court has also brought war crimes charges against two top Russian military officers for overseeing a missile and drones strikes on Ukrainian civilian targets such as electricity grids and residential homes.
